entry.title: Empowering Healthcare Innovation with SAP Generative AI Hub
entry.content:
Unlocking Healthcare's Future: With SAP Generative AI Hub, you can start your Business AI journey, education and experience at your hospital or research organization by implementing Large-Language-Models (LLM) based use cases at low risk and low invest while having a portfolio of leading models of choice.

There is no healthcare without innovation and AI is paramount for this, at least since AI left the laboratories back at Davos in 2022. Hospitals and research institutions need modern and state of the art tools to enhance patient care, streamline processes, and accelerate research. This is where the SAP Generative AI Hub, built on the robust foundation of SAP AI Core, emerges not just as a tool, but as a strategic partner. It e.g., provides a secure, scalable, and intelligent bridge for hospitals and research institutions to harness the power of Large Language Models (LLMs) responsibly and effectively.

An Elegant and Strategic Entry into AI, Without the Lock-in

For many healthcare CIOs, committing to a single LLM provider feels like a high stakes bet. The SAP Generative AI Hub masterfully resolves this dilemma. It functions as an abstraction layer, providing a single, consistent interface to a multitude of LLMs. This ‘future-proofs’ your AI strategy, allowing you to adopt superior, medically-trained models as they emerge and with minimal disruption. This agility allows organizations to start their AI journey with confidence, knowing they are not tied to a single technology but are instead investing in a flexible, evolving ecosystem.

The Vision: An Intelligent Data Layer to Empower Clinicians

The true revolution, however, lies beyond simply accessing an AI model. The ultimate vision is one where AI tools operate upon a unified enterprise and clinical data layer. Imagine e.g., a foundational data platform that intelligently consolidates information from disparate systems into a single, cohesive, longitudinal patient record.

It is upon this unified foundation that the SAP Generative AI Hub operates at its full potential. It becomes the intelligent reasoning engine that could help e.g., clinicians to interact with a patient's complete journey through natural language. Instead of spending hours piecing together a patient's history, a clinician can ask complex questions that were previously impossible to answer efficiently:

  • "Summarize this patient's full clinical history from the lab systems, highlighting any imaging findings relevant to their current complaint."
  • "Analyze the latest pathology report in the context of the patient's genomic profile and suggest relevant clinical trials."
  • "Compare the progression of this patient's tumor markers against anonymized data from similar patient cohorts and flag any statistical anomalies."

This shifts the clinician's role from a data retriever to a data interpreter and strategic decision-maker. The AI handles the assembly and synthesis of information, freeing the clinician to focus on what truly matters: complex diagnosis, treatment planning, and patient care.

Elevating Prompt Engineering from an Art to a Science with AI Launchpad

To enable such powerful interaction, the AI must be guided with precision by normal users like a clinician without e.g., relying on or demanding limited expert IT staff. This is supported by the SAP AI Launchpad that transforms prompt engineering from an ad-hoc activity into a managed, enterprise-grade discipline.

  • Seamless Integration into clinical workflows: The prompts and models managed in AI Launchpad can be seamlessly integrated into applications like the EMR. With a single click, a clinician e.g., can trigger a pre-approved prompt to generate a referral letter, drawing on data from across the unified layer without ever leaving their primary workflow.
  • A Centralized Playground for Experimentation: The Launchpad provides a sandbox environment to test prompts across different LLMs. A clinical researcher can test prompts to see which model can most accurately synthesize a patient's history from the unified data layer for a cohort study.
  • Enterprise-Grade Lifecycle Management for Prompts: A well-crafted prompt is a valuable asset. The AI Launchpad allows you to version, test, and deploy them across the organization, ensuring that if a clinical guideline changes, all relevant prompts can be updated instantly for consistent, high-quality output.
  • Fostering Collaboration and Standardization: The AI Launchpad creates a central ‘prompt library’, breaking down departmental silos. A prompt perfected by the radiology department to analyze imaging reports could be adapted by the oncology department, accelerating innovation across the institution.

A Fortress of Security for Consolidated Health Information

The consolidation of such comprehensive patient data onto a single logical layer elevates the importance of an uncompromising security architecture. The idea of sending this sensitive data to external AI services is a non-starter. The SAP Generative AI Hub is designed as a secure proxy that mitigates these risks.

By routing all interactions through the hub, which runs on the secure SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), hospitals gain a central point of control. It allows for the consistent application of security policies, access controls, and data anonymization techniques before any data leaves the organization's secure environment. This creates a trusted framework where the immense power of generative AI can be leveraged without compromising on patient privacy or regulatory compliance.

One Contract, a World of Possibilities

Navigating the procurement and legal complexities of multiple AI vendor contracts is a significant drain on resources. The SAP Generative AI Hub eliminates this by offering access to a diverse portfolio of leading LLMs through a single commercial agreement with SAP. This grants your institution the agility to use the best model for understanding clinical terminology and another for analyzing operational data, all without being bogged down by procurement cycles.

Conclusion

The SAP Generative AI Hub is more than a platform; it is a critical component of a visionary strategy to unlock the true potential of integrated clinical data. By providing secure, flexible access to the world's most advanced AI models, it lays the groundwork for a future where clinicians are empowered with complete, synthesized information at the point of care. It’s time to move beyond the hype and begin building a more intelligent, efficient, and personalized healthcare system for everyone.

 

Sources for Inspiration

  • Unleashing the Power of SAP AI Launchpad & SAP AI Core: Create Your First AI Application
  • SAP AI Launchpad Community Page
  • SAP AI Core is All You Need

entry.title: Mastering Price Precedence in SAP Subscription Billing: A Guide to Specific-to-Generic Lookups
entry.content:
Introduction: The Universal Pricing Challenge

As a pricing expert, you know the challenge: you have standard list prices but also need special rates for key customers. This creates a price hierarchy that your system must navigate correctly.

How do you configure SAP Subscription Billing to reliably search for a customer-specific price first, and then fall back to the standard price only if no special rate is found?

This post guides you through implementing this "specific-to-generic" search using two powerful alternative patterns: a multi-table approach for clear separation and a single-table approach for consolidated management.

 

The Business Scenario: Prioritizing Customer Rates

Our goal is to apply a customer-specific price if one exists; otherwise, the system must automatically use the standard list price.

To build this, our pricing logic will use the fields productCode, marketId, rateElement, and the key differentiator, customerId. To keep this example clear, we will focus on one recurring charge and use new lookup tables, but the pattern applies to other charge types and can be adapted for existing tables.

 

Solution Part 1: The Multi-Table Approach - Clear Separation

This intuitive method uses separate tables for customer-specific and standard prices, cleanly separating the data. It's ideal when different teams are responsible for managing these distinct price sets.

Step 1: Create Two Distinct Lookup Tables

First, create two separate lookup tables to house the different price levels.

  • Z_PSS_CUSTOMER_PRICES: Holds special prices for key customers.
    • Inputs: productCode, marketId, rateElement, customerId
    • Output: price
  • Z_PSS_STANDARD_PRICES: Holds general list prices.
    • Inputs: productCode, marketId, rateElement
    • Output: price

The following screenshots show the content of the lookup tables for an example product and customer.

Customer-specific prices: 

Standard prices: 

 

Step 2: Design the Sequential Pricing Logic

In your price element specification, build a pricing tree to perform the lookups in the correct order.

  1. Attempt specific lookup: First, access the Z_PSS_CUSTOMER_PRICES table. If a match is found, the price is set and the logic concludes.
  2. Fall back to generic lookup: Nested under the "else" path of the first step, this lookup accesses the Z_PSS_STANDARD_PRICES table to find the list price if no customer-specific price was found.

The pricing tree looks as follows:

A note on scalability: This pattern is easily extendable. You can create a deeper hierarchy (for example: Customer Price -> Customer Group Price -> Standard Price) by adding more tables and sequential lookup steps.

 

Solution Part 2: The Single-Table Approach - Consolidated & Elegant

This alternative centralizes all prices into a single table, reducing configuration objects and simplifying maintenance, especially when one person manages all rates.

Step 1: Create One Consolidated Lookup Table

Create one table structured to hold both specific and generic prices.

  • Z_PSS_ALL_PRICES: Holds both customer-specific and standard list prices.
    • Inputs: productCode, marketId, rateElement, customerId
    • Output: price

The key is data discipline. Customer-specific rows contain the actual customerId. To mark rows as generic, you use a dedicated constant. While any consistent value works (like '#'), for this example we will use an empty string.

Customer-specific and standard prices:

Step 2: Design the "Two-Pass" Pricing Logic

The pricing tree now performs two lookups against the same table.

  1. First pass (specific): Access Z_PSS_ALL_PRICES using the actual customerId from the subscription.
  2. Second pass (generic): If the first lookup finds nothing, perform a second lookup on the same table. This time, map the customerId input from a constant value — the empty string we defined for generic prices.

The pricing tree looks as follows:

 

A Key Consideration: Lookups Require Exact Matches

A crucial detail: lookup tables perform an exact match on all specified inputs. They don't support wildcards ('*') or treat empty fields as optional.

This makes strict data consistency essential, especially for the single-table pattern. The constant value in your logic — in our case, the empty string — must exactly match the value in the table's customerId column for generic rows, or the lookup will fail.

 

Pros and Cons: Which Strategy is Right for You?

Choosing the right pattern depends on your business requirements and operational complexity.

Multi-Table Approach:

  • Pros: Clear and easy to understand. Great for separating data management across teams. Scales well for complex hierarchies.
  • Cons: More configuration objects (lookup tables) to manage.

Single-Table Approach:

  • Pros: Fewer configuration objects. A single source of truth for all prices simplifies maintenance.
  • Cons: Requires strict data consistency. Can become complex to manage if more hierarchy levels are added.

 

Conclusion: Building Your Price Hierarchy with Confidence

SAP Subscription Billing offers the flexibility to model sophisticated price precedence rules. Whether you use a multi-table or single-table approach, you can ensure the system always finds the right price.

Success depends on a well-defined search path and consistent data. We hope this guide helps you implement robust pricing, and we invite you to share your thoughts or questions in the comments below.

 

Further Reading

  • Official SAP Help Portal: Price Element Specifications
  • Official SAP Help Portal: Lookup Tables

entry.title: Re: Using Technical User in SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
Hi @anton-malyshev,

For everyone else who still getting 403 - the scoped role that gives enough permissions to get data via OData service is DW Scoped Viewer. Would be nice to hear from SAP what exact permissions are needed for the role to allow data consuming via OData. 

Thanks for you question, To consume data exposed by APIs you must have a scoped role that grants you access to a space with the following privileges:

  • Data Warehouse Consumption (-R------)
  • Space Files (-R------)
  • Data Warehouse Data Builder (-R------)

The DW Scoped Viewer standard role contains those privileges.  Those permissions are documented on the Consumption API SAP Help page.

Thanks for the feedback I will adapt the blog content to contain those details about permissions.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model Data Import to SAP Analytics Cloud using RFA JS
entry.content:
We are now familiar with the integration between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM), thanks to the blog posts How SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) pulls data from SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) and How to setup Model View OData.

With this integration and the use of MultiAction in SAC, we can easily perform data calculations in SAP PaPM Cloud SM and reporting processed data in SAC.

In addition, with the integration topic above, SAC provides a Data Import Service that enables users to import master data and facts into an existing SAC model. This API can be called in SAP PaPM Cloud SM by using the Remote Function Adapter JavaScript (RFA JS).

Therefore, even without the usage of MultiAction in SAC, SAP PaPM Cloud SM can perform a data import towards an existing SAC Model.

On this blog post, what I am going to show is how we can utilize the RFA JS to perform a data import to SAC.

Prerequisites

  • You have an existing model in SAC. See Create a New Model.
  • Environment to be used in SAP PaPM Cloud SM. See Environment.
  • Existing OAuth Client to be used in the creation of Destination. See Manage OAuth Clients.
  • Created Destination in SAP BTP. See, How to setup Model View OData.

Procedure

Empty SAC Model

Here’s the SAC Model that we are going to perform a data import. This model is totally empty for us to see the imported data records later from our Run in SAP PaPM Cloud SM.

You can take note of the Model ID above in the URL as it will be used later on our script.

Add new property to your existing destination.

RFA JS can call BTP Destination. Administrators can put additional properties “IsInjectable” set to “true” for us to be able to use this Destination on our RFA JS script.

If this property is not added, then an error will occur that the destination “IsInjectable” property is not set to “true” like the image below:

Modeling setup

To demonstrate how the writing functions when we use RFA JS, I will only use basic data fields.

Model Table Input

The expectation is these data records above will be imported on our empty SAC Model.

Note: All data records for Dimension fields that will be passed to SAC model should be included in the Dimension Table. Data that are not included will be disregarded upon import. For more information, see api/v1/dataimport.

RFA JavaScript configuration

The RFA JS we have created will make the Model Table above as our Input. In addition, all available fields are added on the selection fields.

For more information on other properties, see JavaScript.

We are going to add now the generic script you can copy and paste on your RFA JS in your environment.

/* 
    Mapping of fields from SAC and SAP PaPM Cloud SM. Fields are case sensitive, please ensure it is in the right format same from SAC and your SAP PaPM Cloud SM.
*/
const FIELDS_MAPPING = {
    // 'SAC_FIELD1_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD1_NAME',
    // 'SAC_FIELD2_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD2_NAME',
    // 'SAC_FIELD3_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD3_NAME'
    'Version': 'VERSION',
    'Date': 'DATE',
    'PRODUCT': 'PRODUCT',
    'CUSTOMER': 'CUSTOMER',
    'AMOUNT': 'AMOUNT',
    'QUANTITY': 'QUANTITY'

};
/*
    Fill line below with SAC connection details, as defined in BTP.
*/
// e.g. SACDES
const BTP_DESTINATION_NAME = 'SACDES';
/*
    Fill line below with SAC details
*/
// e.g. Cdgqgo84cv2pmkud7lpl3k6e4p
const SAC_MODEL_NAME = 'Cdgqgo84cv2pmkud7lpl3k6e4p';

/*
    Do not modify lines below.
*/
const { clientId, clientSecret, tokenServiceURL, URL } = getBtpHttpDestination(BTP_DESTINATION_NAME);
const authTokenResponse = fetchSync(`${tokenServiceURL}?grant_type=client_credentials`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': `Basic ${btoa(`${clientId}:${clientSecret}`)}`,
        }
    }
);
if (authTokenResponse.status !== 200) {
    console.error('Error while fetching auth token!', JSON.stringify(authTokenResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while fetching auth token!');
}

const authToken = 'Bearer ' + authTokenResponse.result.access_token;
const csrfResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/csrf`, 'text', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': 'fetch',
            'x-sap-sac-custom-auth': 'true',
        }
    }
);
if (csrfResponse.status !== 200) {
    console.error('Error while fetching CSRF token!', JSON.stringify(authTokenResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while fetching CSRF token!');
}
const xCsrfToken = csrfResponse.headers['x-csrf-token'];
const cookie = csrfResponse.headers['set-cookie'];

const createJobBody = JSON.stringify({ Mapping: FIELDS_MAPPING})
const createJobResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/models/${SAC_MODEL_NAME}/factData`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body: createJobBody,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (createJobResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while creating a job!', JSON.stringify(createJobResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while creating a job!');
}

const jobId = createJobResponse.result.jobID
const dataToExport = scope.data;
const body = JSON.stringify({ 'Data': dataToExport });

const addRowsResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (addRowsResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while adding rows to job!', JSON.stringify(addRowsResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while adding rows to job!');
}

if (addRowsResponse.result.failedNumberRows > 0) {
    console.error('Invalid rows found!', JSON.stringify(addRowsResponse.result));
    throw new Error('Invalid rows found!');
}

const runJobResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}/run`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (runJobResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while starting job run!', JSON.stringify(runJobResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while starting job run!');
}

const timeoutTime = Date.now() + 20 * 1000;
const interval = 2 * 1000;
while(Date.now() < timeoutTime) {
    Atomics.wait(new Int32Array(new SharedArrayBuffer(4)), 0, 0, interval);
    const jobStatusResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}/status`, 'json', {
            headers: {
                'Authorization': authToken,
                'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
                cookie,
                'Content-Type': 'application/json'
            }
        }
    );

    if (jobStatusResponse.status !== 200) {
        console.error('Error while checking job status!', JSON.stringify(jobStatusResponse));
        throw new Error('Error while checking job status!');
    }
    if (jobStatusResponse.result.jobStatus === 'COMPLETED') {
        console.success('SAC Import was successful!');
        break;
    }
    if (jobStatusResponse.result.jobStatus === 'FAILED') {
        console.error('SAC Import was not successful!', JSON.stringify(jobStatusResponse));
        throw new Error('Error during SAC Import!');
    }
}

Disclaimer: This is just a generic script that can be used in RFA JS. In case you have some issues with the syntax, please communicate with your JavaScript expert.

Once the script is added, you may now proceed on the Activation and Run of your RFA JS function. Successful run will show a message log like this:

After the Run of RFA JS, we may now proceed checking our empty SAC Model if the data records are successfully imported.

Data import using the RFA JS from SAP PaPM Cloud SM uses he default method which is Update. In this case, the Run of RFA JS performs an upsert on the target model.

Dimensions in SAC are treated as keys, then If a row in the imported data matches all the dimensions of a row in the target model, that row will be updated. If there is no match from the source row then it will be inserted as a new row.

For more information, see Model Job Settings.

To give an example, let’s say I have updated my data records from my model table input.

Highlighted with Green – these data records will only update our SAC Model in terms of Amount and Quantity. This is expected as it will match the existing data records we have imported earlier from previous step.

Highlighted with Red – since we are using the method Update in our data import from RFA JS, nothing will happen for these three(3) data records as it already exists in our SAC model that uses the dimension

Highlighted with Orange – the dimensions for this data records are all unique. Therefore, this will be inserted as a new row.

Highlighted with Blue – this data records are not available in our Dimension table, then this will be disregarded from our data import.

Fast forward to the Run of RFA JS, here’s the result in our SAC model. The order was changed as it depends on the latest data rows that are recently updated.

As explained above, the data records highlighted with red are not updated as we do not have any changes from our model table input. While we have a new data record which is highlighted with orange as it doesn’t any matches in terms of Dimensions in our SAC Model. Other than that, we have the data records highlighted with green which were updated in terms of AMOUNT and QUANTITY columns.

Lastly, we cannot see the data record highlighted with blue as the PROD0X and CUST0X values are not included on our dimension table for PRODUCT and CUSTOMER fields from our target sac model.

Okay! This is the end of our blog post and I hope I have provided you an information that can be use for your demos or projects when using the SAP PaPM Cloud SM integration with SAC.

You may follow our tag PaPMCloudSMIntegration to see all available blog post discussing integration topics.

See you again on my next blog!

entry.title: AI & Automation in Field Service: Espresso Session for Energy & Utilities
entry.content:
Join us for a focused 30-minute Espresso Session designed specifically for service-driven organizations in energy and utilities. Through an engaging demo, we’ll showcase how SAP Field Service Management (FSM) is evolving with AI and automation—from today’s assistive capabilities to tomorrow’s autonomous field operations. Discover how integrated asset and service management, AI-powered scheduling, and mobile execution help energy providers respond faster, optimize resources, and deliver resilient, community-focused service in times of crisis and in daily operations.

  • Seamless Digital Handover: See how SAP Cloud ERP and FSM connect assets, work orders, and customer data in a single source of truth—enabling faster, smarter decision-making across critical infrastructure.
  •  AI-Enhanced Dispatching: Explore the SAP FSM Dispatcher Agent with Joule for natural-language scheduling, explainable AI for auto-scheduling, and semi-autonomous optimization to handle real-time changes.
  • Technician Empowerment with AI: Learn how generative AI can draft service reports,and provide knowledge assistance on-site to close skill gaps and boost first-time fix rates.
  • Assisted Work Capture & Compliance: Experience how technicians use AI-infused mobile apps to receive prioritized work orders, guided procedures, and real-time safety insights—online or offline—while seamlessly documenting their work. Photos, checklists, and customer signatures flow back into the Cloud ERP, ensuring accuracy, compliance, and streamlined billing.
  • Strategic Vision for Energy and Utilities: Discover SAP’s long-term commitment to energy and utilities, including advanced capabilities in schedule, crew, and crowd management, service mapping, and meter and distribution operations.

This session is ideal for field service managers, operations leaders, dispatchers and IT professionals responsible for service delivery, emergency response, or digital transformation initiatives who want to enhance service efficiency, reduce downtime, and deliver a superior customer experience through intelligent, connected field operations

 

👉Register now for our 30-minute session on October 1, 2025 at 4:00 PM CET to explore the future of intelligent field service: https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5067733/B505A11C1DC20585AB6B650A2068C8FE

entry.title: WalkMe digital Learning - Digitale Kompetenz im Arbeitsfluss
entry.content:
Dieser Blog ist eine Übersetzung des Artikels: WalkMe reimagines digital learning to close the enterprise skills gap in the flow of work vom 16.09.2025 incl. einer kurzen Reflektion zum Schluss

Im Blog stellt WalkMe eine neue digitale Lernlösung vor, die mit Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI) Unternehmen dabei unterstützt, die Kompetenz ihrer Mitarbeitenden nachhaltig zu steigern, indem Schulungen direkt in die täglich genutzten Tools integriert werden.

Ein Großteil betrieblicher Weiterbildung und IT Training findet immer noch viel zu früh und zu weit entfernt vom eigentlichen Arbeitsprozess statt. Die kognitive Wissenschaft zeigt: Bis zu 90% der vermittelten Informationen werden innerhalb einer Woche wieder vergessen. Wenn Mitarbeitende sich nicht an Lerninhalte erinnern können, müssen sie diese mühsam suchen – 62% der Beschäftigten berichten, dass sie bei der Arbeit zu viel Zeit mit Informationssuche verbringen.

WalkMe setzt einen neuen Standard für Lernen im Unternehmen und reagiert auf das gestiegene Tempo des Wandels in der Arbeitswelt. Die neue Lösung verankert zentrale Kompetenzen direkt in den Anwendungen, die Mitarbeitende täglich nutzen – auch, wenn Arbeitsabläufe sich über mehrere Tools erstrecken. Mithilfe intelligenter, KI-basierter Autorentools können Teams Trainingsinhalte in großem Umfang erstellen und verwalten. So entsteht eine umfassende Infrastruktur für zeitgemäßes, eingebettetes Lernen.

Statement von Dan Adika, CEO und Mitgründer von WalkMe: „Lernen sollte sich mit der Arbeit bewegen, anpassen und nahtlos einfügen. Deshalb haben wir eine KI-native, moderne Lösung geschaffen, bei der Erstellen und Pflegen von Lerninhalten mühelos sind. Das ist Lernen, neu gedacht – kontinuierlich, effektiv und immer in Bewegung.“

Eine Erweiterung des traditionellen Lernens für die Zukunft der Arbeit

Die meisten Lernangebote finden heute noch vor dem eigentlichen Arbeitsprozess statt – in Kursen, Portalen oder starren Modulen. Das Ergebnis: Mitarbeitende vergessen das Gelernte oder können das Wissen im entscheidenden Moment nicht anwenden.

Das sogenannte "Learning in the Flow of Work", also Lernen im Arbeitsfluss, ist daher eine wichtige Ergänzung zu traditionellen Ansätzen. Es bietet kontextbezogene Schulungen genau dann, wenn sie gebraucht werden und erleichtert damit die praktische Anwendung und den Zugang zu relevanten Lerninhalten im richtigen Moment. Ein Beispiel: Eine Einkaufssachbearbeiterin erhält beim Erstellen eines Auftrags einen Hinweis zu Datenschutzvorgaben, oder ein HR-Manager bekommt für die Erstellung eines Feedbacks direkt Mikrolerninhalte angezeigt.

Das sind keine losgelösten Lernerlebnisse mehr, sondern gezielte, just-in-time eingesteuerte Impulse, die wirken, wenn die Kompetenz wirklich gebraucht wird.

Intro von neuen Ansätzen für digitales Lernen

WalkMe folgt einem neuen, KI first Ansatz. Die Lösung vereint intelligente Erstellung und Auslieferung von Lerninhalten in der Anwendung selbst und macht somit den Arbeitsprozess zum direkten Lernweg.

Zentrale Funktionen beinhalten:

  • Umfassende Bereitstellung von Training: Such- und Konsumierungsfunktionen je nach Nutzerverhalten direkt in der Anwendung, individuell anpassbare Lernportale.

  • Intelligente Inhaltserstellung: Skalierbare, KI-gestützte Content-Erstellung auf Basis von Prompts und Unternehmenswissen, inklusive Multimedia, Multimodalität und In-App Simulationen.

  • Effektive Wissensverankerung: Trainingsinhalte werden dort ausgespielt, wo die Lernbereitschaft am höchsten ist – mit flexiblen Auslösern, kontextsensitiven KI-basierten Empfehlungen und Segmentierung nach Nutzerverhalten.

Begleitet werden diese Funktionen von leistungsstarken Analytics, mit denen sich das Nutzungsverhalten und die Effektivität von Trainings zuverlässig messen lassen.

Was bedeutet das für SAP-Kunden?

  • WalkMe Kunden können den Impact Ihrer DAP Programme optimieren durch die Kombination von Tun & Lernen. WalkMe Digital Adoption unterstützt die effiziente Ausführung von Arbeitsabläufen, während das WalkMe-Learning Produkt gezielt zentrale Lernziele im jeweiligen Kontext und direkt im Arbeitsfluss stärkt, um nachhaltige Fähigkeiten und Kompetenzentwicklung bei den Mitarbeitenden zu fördern.
     

  • SAP Enable Now-Kunden können auf die neue Lösung migrieren und erhalten neue Möglichkeiten wie KI-gestützte Kurserstellung, erweiterte Analysen und rollenbasierte Bereitstellung – für jede Anwendung, ob SAP oder andere. Daneben besteht SCORM Interoperability und robuste Analytics für Autoren & Lernende. 

  • Inhalte aus SAP Enable Now, inklusive Simulationen und Bücher, sind weiterhin nutzbar und editierbar mit der neuen Lösung.

  • SAP SuccessFactors Learning-Kunden profitieren durch die Integration von KI-gestützter Inhaltserstellung, Simulationen und Quiz, die direkt in SuccessFactors Learning veröffentlicht werden können.

Fazit: Kontinuierliche Entwicklung in unsicheren Zeiten

Seit über einem Jahrzehnt prägt WalkMe die Entwicklung digitaler Unterstützungslösungen. Mit dem neuen Lernangebot vollzieht das Unternehmen die nächste Entwicklungsstufe und verbindet die Stärken der Digital Adoption Platform mit modernen Learning-Komponenten: Lernen im Moment des Bedarfs, nahtlos über alle Tools und Rollen hinweg, basierend auf einer tiefgehenden Analyse von Lernverhalten und Kompetenzlücken.

Der Beta-Test läuft bereits, die generelle Verfügbarkeit folgt noch in diesem Jahr. Unternehmen, die Wandlungsdruck spüren und ihre Teams schnell weiterentwickeln müssen, finden mit der neuen WalkMe-Lösung die Brücke zwischen Strategie und Praxis.

"Nicht die Systeme werden smarter, sondern die Menschen. Und darauf kommt es an."

Weitere Infos & Demos

Direkt vom WalkMe Team

  • Request a personalized demo
  • Explore migration options from SAP Enable Now (Blog der Product Ownerin)

Want a closer look? Pre-register for our upcoming webinar to save your seat.

 
Wir werden zusätzlich im November ein allgemeines Webinar in deutscher Sprache allgemein zu WalkMe anbieten - sowie im Januar eins zum neuen WalkMe Learning Offering, speziell auch für SAP Enable Now Kunden. 

Persönliches Fazit von mir

Aus meiner Sicht bietet WalkMe mit seiner KI-nativen Lern-Lösung einen zeitgemäßen  Ansatz, um Lernen im Kontext der täglichen Arbeit wirklich wirksamer zu machen. Die Verzahnung von Learning und Digital Adoption ist ein entscheidender Schritt. Vielen Unkenrufen, auch im deutschen Markt, wird das Thema digital Learning nicht platt gemacht und damit SAP Enable Now. Vielmehr wird die Chance genutzt ein Cloud first, AI first Lern- und Wissens Autorensystem auf der führenden WalkMe Plattform zu entwickeln. Denn wenn wir ehrlich sind: SAP Enable Now war nicht nur vom UI her schon in die Jahre gekommen (wie andere Tools im Markt). 

Insbesondere finde ich wertvoll, wie WalkMe klassische Lern-Lösungen wie  SuccessFactors Learning intelligent erweitert. Und für SAP Enable Now Kunden wird es eine spannende Zukunft geben. Das sorgt für Investitionsschutz und bringt Unternehmen in die Lage, bestehende Inhalte und Strukturen weiterhin zu nutzen, aber durch KI und Automation deutlich effektiver zu gestalten. 

Wie oben erwähnt werden wir demnächst Info- und Austauschformate zum Produkt sowie zu den Details für bestehende SAP Enable Now Kunden hier in der Community veröffentlichen.

entry.title: Integration Advisor: complex mapping code for dimension conversion in SAP B2B
entry.content:
Introduction

In many B2B integration scenarios, it’s common to encounter values that must be converted depending on a specific dimension—such as weight, length, volume, or even currency. Each of these dimensions can have multiple possible units, and the integration process must ensure that the target payload uses the correct unit and precision.

For instance, this article uses a weight conversion example involving kilograms (KGM), grams (GRM), and decigrams (DG). However, similar challenges arise with other measurements, eg. centimeters vs. meters, liters vs. milliliters, or different currency codes with varying decimal rules. Without proper handling, these mismatches can cause data errors, disrupt downstream processes, and lead to costly corrections.

At present, the Integration Advisor’s Mapping Guideline (MAG) does not include built-in functions for this type of unit-based calculation with dynamic precision control. However such functionality can be implemented by applying an XSLT transformation MAGs.

In this blog, we will explore an XSLT-based approach using the KGM/GRM/DG case as an example and the same pattern can be adapted to many other dimensions in B2B integration scenarios.

Example: Mapping Quantity with UnitCode from EDIFACT to SAP SOAP

Let´s assume that a trading partner X sends an UN/EDIFACT D.10B Purchase orders to my company, and we want to receive OrderRequest as an SOAP message.

In the source message, the data element “6060” quantity and “6411” measurement unit code in the segment “QTY”. And the data element “unitCode” unitCode and “CONTENT” quantity in the segment “RequestedQuantity” of the target message.

 

We assume that my company expects the quantity with the unit KGM, therefore in order to handle a mapping from source path /ORDERS/SG29/QTY where the data element 6063 equals KGM/GRM/DG, to target path /OrderRequest/Order/OrderItem/RequestedQuantity with the attribute unitCode="KGM", we will need the following steps.

  • In the target MIG(Message Implementation Guidelines), select and assign Codelist to the unitCode. Then qualifer the segment “RequestedQuantity” with KGM.

 

  • In the Shared Code of MAG(Mapping Guidelines), input the following xslt code with the name fx_sumOfDimensionValues_in_KGM. Then it is possible to assign this shared code into mapping function for the quantity mapping.
<xsl:variable name="vFraction" select="'4'" />
<xsl:variable name="vFraString"
    select="string-join(for $i in 1 to xs:integer($vFraction) return '0', '')" />
<xsl:variable name="vSum" select="
  if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'GRM') then 
    xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060) div 1000)
  else if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'DG') then 
    xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060) div 100)
  else if (upper-case($nodes_in[1]/D_6411) = 'KGM') then xs:decimal(sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060))
  else sum($nodes_in[1]/D_6060)
"/>
<xsl:value-of select="format-number($vSum, concat('#0.', $vFraString))" />

This snippet first defines a variable $vFraction to control the decimal precision dynamically. In this case, the value is set to 4, meaning that the final output will always display up to four decimal places. The second variable, $vFraString, creates a string of zeros corresponding to the precision length, which is later used by the format-number() function to ensure consistent formatting.

The heart of the logic is in the $vSum variable. Here, we inspect the unit code from the source element D_6411 and apply the appropriate conversion:

  • GRM → KGM: Divide by 1,000 (grams to kilograms)
  • DG → KGM: Divide by 100 (decigrams to kilograms)
  • KGM → KGM: No conversion needed, the value is used as-is
  • Fallback: If the unit code does not match any of the above, the raw value is used without conversion

Finally, format-number() applies the desired precision formatting by combining #0. with the zero string generated earlier. This ensures that regardless of the original format, the resulting value in the target XML will adhere to a consistent numeric pattern—essential for downstream systems that rely on strict schema validation.

 

Adapting the Pattern for Other Dimensions

Although this example focuses on weight conversion, the same approach can be applied to other measurable dimensions. For example:

  • Length: mm ↔ cm ↔ m
  • Volume: ml ↔ L ↔ m³
  • Currency: adjusting for minor units (e.g., cents vs. yen)
  • Custom Units: industry-specific codes with defined conversion ratios

The main changes involve:

  1. Adjusting the if/else if logic to account for the specific unit codes you expect in the source.
  2. Modifying the conversion factor according to the required unit transformation.
  3. Setting $vFraction to match the level of precision required by your target system.

 

Summary

By embedding this logic directly into the MAG’s XSLT, you gain:

  • Dynamic Unit Handling: No need to pre-normalize values outside the integration flow.
  • Precision Control: Flexible decimal formatting without post-processing.
  • Reusability: The pattern can be packaged as a reusable function and applied across multiple mappings.

This approach ensures your integration not only transforms the data structure but also intelligently adapts values, reducing manual intervention and preventing costly data mismatches.

entry.title: Unlocking a Cleaner and Greener Energy Future with AI
entry.content:
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) mandate rapid clean energy adoption to combat climate change. However, many utilities still face hurdles integrating renewables such as solar, wind, and hydropower into increasingly intelligent, distributed grids. Digital transformation, powered by AI, can enable accurate forecasting, predictive analytics, and IoT-driven self-healing grids, unlocking a sustainable future at scale.

Gartner projects that by 2027, over 50% of enterprise AI models will be industry-specific, up from about 1% in 2023. For utilities, this shift toward domain-tuned AI accelerates adoption in forecasting, asset performance, and customer operations. IDC’s Utilities predictions and Forrester’s Generative AI outlook similarly point to a pivot from pilot to production, with measured value in core operational use cases

AI Use Cases and SAP Utilities Solutions:

  • Advanced Renewable Forecasting: AI brings together historical generation, weather, and grid conditions to predict renewable output, enhance grid stability, and optimize dispatch. SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), SAP Datasphere for data fabric, and SAP S/4HANA Utilities for integration.
  • Intelligent Demand-Side Management: AI dynamically adjusts loads across sectors - smart appliances, EVs, industrial processes balancing supply and reducing peaks. SAP enablers: SAP Cloud for Utilities, SAP BRIM and SAP Subscription Billing for innovative tariffs, and SAC for optimization.
  • Proactive Predictive Maintenance: AI-driven anomaly detection improves asset reliability and avoids costly outages. SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), and SAP S/4HANA Asset Management.

What are the opportunities of converging AI and SAP Solutions?

  • Reliability & Predictive Maintenance at Scale
    AI models fuse SCADA, asset history, and condition data to detect anomalies early, optimize spares, and move from time-based to condition-based maintenance - cutting SAIDI/SAIFI and truck rolls.

SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), SAP S/4HANA Asset Management, SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for predictive insights.

  • DER Orchestration, Flexibility & Market Settlement
    Forecasting and dispatching behind-the-meter solar, storage, EVs, and microgrids; forming virtual power plants (VPPs)  and optimizing participation in flexibility/ancillary markets.

SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM) for metering and settlement, SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) and SAP Subscription Billing for new tariffs and flexibility services, SAP S/4HANA Utilities for end-to-end customer-to-cash, and SAP Analytics Cloud for forecast optimization.

  • Customer & Prosumer Experience (CX) and Personalized Energy Services
    Hyper-personalized advisory, usage insights, TOU nudges, EV-smart-charging offers, and prosumer engagement that drive satisfaction and reduce churn.

SAP enablers: SAP S/4HANA Utilities, SAP BRIM for complex pricing/bundles, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), SAP Service Cloud, and SAP Marketing Cloud for tailored engagement.

  • Sustainability, Emissions & “Green AI” Operations
    AI to optimize dispatch, reduce losses, and cut emissions; automated Scope 1–3 tracking and audit-ready reporting; and energy-efficient AI practices to minimize compute footprints.

SAP enablers: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) for KPI governance, SAP Product Footprint Management (PFM) for footprint calculations, SAP Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) for operational compliance, and SAP Signavio for process redesign.

  • Workforce Productivity, Safety & Knowledge Capture
    AI copilots for planners/dispatchers; mobile assistants for field technicians (procedures, PPE checks, hazards); automated close-outs and claims; and computer vision for safety observance.

SAP enablers: SAP Field Service Management (FSM) (mobile work), SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) (procedures & failure modes), SAP EHS (permits/safety), SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Enable Now for just-in-time guidance.

  • Revenue Innovation & Margin Protection
    AI-informed margin management (hedging, loss reduction), prosumer/VPP monetization, dynamic pricing, flexibility services, and performance-based programs.

SAP enablers: SAP BRIM, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM), SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere (data fabric for scenario modeling).

Let's look at the challenges and practical mitigations

  • Data Foundations, Quality & Interoperability: Model performance hinges on clean, timely, connected data across OT (SCADA, AMI, APM) and IT (billing, CRM).

Mitigations with SAP: Establish a utility data fabric with SAP Datasphere; unify meter/market data via SAP EDM; standardize models in SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP); use SAP Integration Suite for OT/IT connectors; govern with SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

  • AI Risk, Governance & Model Compliance (AI TRiSM/Responsible AI): Bias, drift, explainability, safety, and regulatory scrutiny (especially for GenAI and automated decisioning).

Mitigations with SAP: Use SAP BTP with SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for lifecycle control; log lineage and approvals; embed human-in-the-loop; instrument KPIs in SAC; codify policies in Signavio.

  • Cybersecurity & Critical Infrastructure Protection: Expanded attack surface across DERs, edge devices, mobile crews, and market interfaces; GenAI introduces new vectors (prompt injection, data leakage).

Mitigations with SAP: Apply least-privilege and policy-based access on SAP BTP; integrate security analytics; segment OT/IT interfaces; harden APIs with SAP Integration Suite; capture end-to-end audit trails.

  • Compute, Energy Footprint & “Green AI”: Training/serving advanced models can inflate energy use, potentially conflicting with utility decarbonization goals.

Mitigations with SAP: Favor smaller, domain-tuned models hosted efficiently on SAP BTP; leverage inference optimization, demand-response scheduling of batch jobs, and carbon-aware routing; track emissions in SAP Sustainability Control Tower and Product Footprint Management.

  • Talent, Change & Operating Model: AI value stalls without product-centric teams, MLOps, and business ownership of outcomes.

Mitigations with SAP: Establish an AI value office; use SAP Signavio for process redesign; adopt MLOps on BTP/AI Launchpad; embed copilot-assisted work in SAP FSM and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Regulatory, Market & Ethical Constraints: Rate design, model explainability, and consumer data use are under tightening scrutiny.

Mitigations with SAP: Keep explainability artifacts for decisions (SAC narratives, model cards in AI Launchpad); enforce privacy-by-design with SAP CDP and consent management; maintain audit trails across EDM/BRIM/market processes.

Conclusion: 

AI is the cornerstone for clean energy transformation. By leveraging SAP’s intelligent utilities solutions and TCS’s innovation, utilities can boost efficiency, integrate renewables, and drive decarbonization. The path to a greener future lies in combining advanced technology with strategic energy management and robust governance. For CXOs, this means making informed, data-driven decisions, ensuring regulatory compliance, and creating sustainable value for customers and shareholders alike. Those who act decisively today will not only navigate the energy transition successfully but also set the benchmark for resilient, future-ready utilities.

entry.title: Re: Setup Time in Production orders not considered correctly
entry.content:
Hello Peter, as I can see, you have not defined any start and end of the capacity, but you have defined a break of 3 hrs. Please remove the break, and try again. Are you using the capacity 001 for scheduling? If yes, I would recommend to maintain start and end time of the maschine. If you define a break, it is considered partially in the scheduling and will lead to the situation you have. Regards Johannes

Calculation: 3hrs break in 24hrs day result in 0,125min break for each minute. If you have standard value of 10 minutes the break will be 10x0,125min = 1,25min; 1,25min +10min = 11,25min duration

entry.title: Re: Option to park FI vendor invoice
entry.content:
With the 'Create Incoming Invoices' it is not possible to Park documents, this is standard design. As an alternative, you can use Fiori app 'Create Supplier Invoice' (F0859) to park supplier invoices. You can check more details in this KBA below:

  • 0002856664 - Create Incoming Invoices app has no park functionality - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In the app Create Supplier Invoice, an invoice can be created without reference to a purchase order. In the details section of Create Supplier Invoice, Document Type can be selected. If you need further details on this, please check the J60 test script accelerator in this link below. Make sure to change to your location before downloading the file. In the file, you will see a section with detailed step-by-step for "Invoice Entry Without Purchase Order" and another to "Park Invoice" using Create Supplier Invoice (F0859):

  • Accounts Payable (J60)

entry.title: Re: Recommended approach for Fiori Adapt UI in S/4H On-Pr...
entry.content:
I had this same issue, client dev-300 for development (with zero data) and dev-100 for data and testing before Q. Not possible to do the UI changes in 300, so forced to use 100, where I was unable to save the changes to TR. I manged find a way to get around the issue.

The route cause is that the client with data was set to Not Modifiable in SCC4.
The fix was using SCC4 to change it temporarily to modifiable and saving the UI changes to a customizing request. Releasing the TR to the quality system afterwards worked, problem solved. I know it's no ideal, but I really struggled to find another way to solve this.

Use the Network tab to see if the POST request when saving is failing, giving this error:

You can check the Response tab to see the message: text: "Client &100& has status 'not modifiable'.

entry.title: Non-MRP-Relevant Storage Location Appears in Stock in APO Product View
entry.content:
Hi everyone,


we’re encountering an issue in the SAP APO Product View for a particular material. A storage location that is not MRP-relevant is unexpectedly appearing in the stock overview, and its quantity is being included in the total available quantity.


In SAP ECC, I’ve checked table T001L, and the storage location is clearly flagged as not relevant for MRP. For other materials that also have stock in this same storage location, the quantity is correctly excluded from the APO Product View.


This leads us to suspect that there might be a material-dependent override somewhere that causes this behavior.
Does anyone know if there’s another configuration point, possibly material-specific, that could influence whether a storage location is considered in APO stock calculations?


Thanks in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Re: How to display custom MIGO fields in Stock – Multiple...
entry.content:
Hello @Tharma 

SAP currently does not permit adding new custom fields directly into the standard Stock – Multiple Materials app (F1595) in Public Cloud.

What is supported is the Data Source Extension to expose existing SAP fields if they are available in the app’s underlying data source.

If you need new attributes, the supported option is to develop a separate custom report or app.


For future changes, the official places to check or request are SAP Road Map Explorer and Customer Influence
Reference: SAP Fiori App Library – F1595 “Stock – Multiple Materials” (App Extensibility)

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Using Technical User in SAP Datasphere Consumption APIs (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
Hi @anton-malyshev,

We expected that DW Scoped Consumer has all necessary permissions but for some reason this one is missing. Is it by design or maybe that can be fixed? 

That is true, for the moment DW Scoped Consumer has not all the permissions required, that is limitation we are aware. We are working on making the "Data Warehouse Data Builder (-R------)" not mandatory for the Consumption APIs, this should be release later this year or early 2026.

If you want to have a scoped role with only those 3 permission, you can:

  1. Create a Custom Role (Non-Scoped) with only the 3 permissions needed and read privilege
  2. Next use this newly created role as the template for creating Custom Scoped Role
  3. Assign the new Custom Scoped Role to you Technical User

This should give you all flexibility to use the least privilege for you consumption technical user

Dear Community,

We are in the process of evaluating the gaps between our Solution Manager ChaRM implementation and SAP Cloud ALM, in preparation for the decomissioning of Solution Manager.

One of the points which is rather critical for us, is the ability of getting a list of the transport requests which will be considered for deployment. Would there be a way to remove this project assignment as a filter? Or would you know of some other way to get this list of features (and respective transport requests) which are in a certain status, belonging to a certain release (or deployment plan)?

Thanks so much!

entry.title: Curriculum Requirements with Retraining
entry.content:
Dear experts,

We are building a curriculum with curriculum requirement, where users need to complete 15 hours out of an item pool by the end of the year. At the beginning of the next year, the item pool is reviewed with some new trainings, but also some old trainings.

Every year, the users need to reach the 15 hours-benchmark again (starting from 0). We should make sure that completing a previously-completed item is prevented, or at least does not contribute in the 15-hour count. This means that every year, the user receives a pool with old and new items, and should obtain 15 training-hours by the end of the year, choosing between the courses that they didn't follow yet. The courses are a mix of e-learnings and instructor-led items, so preventing registrations via the internal is not sufficient.

Could you please advice me how to build such process?

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matchin...
entry.content:
Hi Martin,

The issue happens because missing daily records make subtotals and totals use different bases for calculation.
The fix is to calculate TotalFTE first at the day level as FTE * Quota.
Then aggregate upwards to month, quarter, or year using SUM of DailyFTE as numerator.
For denominator, count only the valid days where data exists (DailyFTE > 0).
This way, Org Units with partial data and those with full data follow the same logic.
As a result, subtotals and overall totals will always align correctly.

entry.title: Update to our Rules of Engagement
entry.content:
We have updated our Rules of Engagement today.

To explain in short what has changed since the last version: 

  • Article 1 now describes the participation etiquette that we expect all community members to follow, as well as outlines the general rules for content publication. For more in-depth information on the participation etiquette and tips for participation in the community, please read this article in our Welcome Corner group. 
  • Article 2 contains information on user profile information. 
  • Article 3 describes content which constitutes "Unacceptable Content". Content that is listed in article 3 may either by rejected or removed. The categories here are now aligned with changes the EU made to the Digital Services Act (DSA) categories this year. All abuse reports under article 3 will be subject to DSA.
  • The old article 3 has been removed, which means publishing content about job opportunities and job postings are no longer permitted in the SAP Community.
  • Article 4 has not changed and remains the same. 

With these updates to our rules of engagement, we continue to ensure the best possible content quality and community experience for our members..

Dear Experts,

Good day...

As per the current requirement ,The customers wants to have the "County"(Residence of Country) Field in Internal Candidate Profile and this value should capture from Employee profile to Candidate Profile. As per the current setup the "County"(Residence of Country)field is not set up as picklist in employee profile, Hence the details not get captured in Candidate Profile in country field when there is a internal Hiring. However when we Changing data type in Employee Profile for country field in Employee central - SF will impact all the downstream system from SF to SAP. Hence We have done an impact analysis and we  found : 

S.No

Option

Feasibility

Comments

1

– EP country field to Candidate profile

No

Data type is different from Employee profile and candidate data model

2

Enable “country of residence” for Internal to edit in respective profiles

No

By standard, this field is not enabled for internals. Based on KBAs it needs to be updated through SM mapping only which we cannot do as per above comment

No

Utilize Phone country / Region in IC job

No

PREM

entry.title: Mapping multiple pay components from SuccessFactors Recruitment to Employee Central
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss an issue relating to mapping multiple pay components from SuccessFactors Recruitment to Employee Central.  This is particularly useful when you want internal hires to go to Manage Pending Hires rather than initiate Onboarding.

In the application template we are saving the amount, frequency and type for four different pay components.  When we move the candidate into Manage Pending Hires we see that there are  multiple rows of data.

The first check was to create a rule trace to see if an Employee Central rule was creating this extra line.  The rule trace confirmed that it was not related to a rule.  

In the mapping template we had multiple rows for each pay component.

The multiple mapping rows for each pay component was causing the issue.  You do not need to map the code, amount and type as three different mappings.  You only need to map one line as shown below, as the amount value sets the pay component with ‘.1001’.

<mapping-attribute><source entity-type="application" refid="offer_HOURLYrateofPay"/><target refid="payComponentRecurring.paycompvalue.1001"/></mapping-attribute>

The frequency does not need to be mapped as this should default from rule in Employee Central.

As mentioned on a previous article you can send internal hires to Manage Pending Hires and review the data there for internal hires before deciding whether you need to initiate an onboarding process.

entry.title: Implementation of a taxable entity across system boundaries (public cloud ↔ private cloud) using DRC
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have a complex requirement in the context of implementing a taxable entity involving company codes from different SAP system landscapes.

Initial situation:

  • The client XXXX XXXX is on an SAP private cloud system with a taxable entity that includes several company codes.
  • XXXX XXXX is now to be included in this taxable entity. However, it is on an SAP public cloud system as a single company code.

Problem:

  • VAT returns are currently submitted on a monthly basis.
  • A manual workaround using the FOTV app (maintenance of an external value) in the private cloud system would be possible in general, but doesn’t go with the requirements of the client
  • During pre-sales, the client was assured that an automated interface between the public cloud and private cloud would be possible, allowing data to be transferred without manual intervention.

Internal discussion status:

  • It was proposed to use Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in a hybrid solution involving Lobster (the XXXX XXXX uses Lobster as a middleware on which all interfaces must be mapped – no BTP + CPI).
  • The client has a total of 5 company codes, 4 in the Private Cloud system and 1 in the Public Cloud system.

Specific questions:

  1. DRC licensing:
  • Which licensing models apply to hybrid use of DRC across public and private clouds?
  • Is licensing based on the number of company codes users, or, for example, the number of documents processed (e.g., blocks of 10,000 invoices)?
  1. Technical functionality:
  • Is it fundamentally possible with DRC to automatically merge company codes from different systems (public cloud ↔ private cloud) for taxable entity?
  • Or is a manual step – such as via FOTV – still necessary?
  1. Lobster integration:
  • Is there any experience or recommendations regarding the integration of Lobster as middleware between public cloud, private cloud, and DRC?
  • What requirements must be fulfilled for DRC to process data from the public cloud system?

Additional information:

  • The relevant DRC component for VAT returns in Germany is: FI-LOC-VAT-DE
  • We are aware that there is a separate DRC scenario for processing external data sources for electronic invoicing however, this does not appear to be the case for reporting. We would appreciate your feedback on the technical and licensing possibilities for implementation, as well as any suggestions for potential solutions. Thank you in advance.

Does anyone have any experience with this kind of topic?

I would appreciate any advice.

Thank you. 

@SAPSupport SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Finance SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Finance SAP Document and Reporting Compliance SAP S/4HANA Finance SAP Tax Classification and Reporting

entry.title: Re: Upload file in XSTRING format in SE38 report program
entry.content:
I'm probably late, but there's a solution to this problem. SAP handles the XSTRING, the hexadecimal string, and not the binary string when I try to display content using the various "viewers" available. So the GUI_UPLOAD solution is valid, but the conversion from BINARY to XSTRING is missing. Here's the code:

  DATA filename            TYPE string.
*  DATA FILETYPE            TYPE CHAR10.
*  DATA HAS_FIELD_SEPARATOR TYPE CHAR01.
*  DATA HEADER_LENGTH       TYPE I.
*  DATA READ_BY_LINE        TYPE CHAR01.
*  DATA DAT_MODE            TYPE CHAR01.
*  DATA CODEPAGE            TYPE ABAP_ENCODING.
*  DATA IGNORE_CERR         TYPE ABAP_BOOL.
*  DATA REPLACEMENT         TYPE ABAP_REPL.
*  DATA VIRUS_SCAN_PROFILE  TYPE VSCAN_PROFILE.
  DATA filelength          TYPE i.
*  DATA HEADER              TYPE XSTRING.
  DATA data_tab            TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tdline.
*  DATA ISSCANPERFORMED     TYPE CHAR01.

  MOVE: url TO filename. "In this example i used variable url that contain the fullpath.

  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload(
    EXPORTING
      filename                = filename
      filetype                = 'BIN'
*      has_field_separator     = SPACE
*      header_length           = 0
*      read_by_line            = 'X'
*      dat_mode                = SPACE
*      codepage                = SPACE
*      ignore_cerr             = ABAP_TRUE
*      replacement             = '#'
*      virus_scan_profile      = virus_scan_profile
    IMPORTING

entry.title: Enhancing Manufacturing Excellence: What's New in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508.1
entry.content:
Welcome to the release highlights for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1 (HFC6). This update continues our commitment to delivering continuous innovation, with a strong focus on enhancing the user experience and operational efficiency for our customers in manufacturing. This post is particularly relevant for professionals in Production Planning, Production Engineering, and Manufacturing roles, as we are introducing several key improvements to help you manage your processes more effectively. I picked one release highlight - you can enjoy it in this short video here:  

 

 

Updates to Process Production Versions 

To improve the efficiency of managing production versions, we have introduced several quality-of-life updates to the Process Production Versions app. When performing mass edits, the system now defaults to background processing, freeing you up to work on other tasks. To prevent errors during cross-plant updates, an information message now appears to help you check for inconsistencies. This helps teams manage their data with greater confidence.

Task List Counter is auto-filled based on the selection of Task List Group while performing mass edits

Furthermore, you can now easily track the status of your mass edits with available logs and benefit from reduced manual entry, as the Task List Counter value is automatically filled when a Task List Group is selected.

 

Gaining Deeper Insights with the Successor to Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders

With the app Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266A), you can monitor the status of production orders or process orders in your area of responsibility. You can check whether the materials included in each order will be available on time and determine components and quantities that are delayed or missing. You can also check whether the milestones defined for an order are met. This helps you react quickly to critical situations and take appropriate actions as required.

As of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1, a successor version of this app is available with the Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266B) app. This new app version will replace the old Monitor Production Orders or Process Orders (F0266A) app in the future. We recommend that you switch to the successor app as soon as possible.

The new app provides an improved look-and-feel based on the Fiori elements framework, while covering all essential features that are available from its predecessor. In addition, it allows you to easily switch between the lists of production orders and process orders without having to access it from different tiles, depending on the type of order that you want to display.

Production orders and process orders are displayed within the same app

 Both production orders and process orders are displayed within the same app.

 

A Refreshed Launchpad Experience for Production Planners

The SAP-delivered space template for Production Planning (SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR) has been updated.

Space Template: Production Planning

If your business users are assigned the Production Planner business role template, they will experience a revised layout and an updated set of applications on their SAP Fiori launchpad. This change is designed to provide Production Planners with a more intuitive and role-based user experience. The updated space surfaces the most relevant apps and information, helping users perform their daily tasks more effectively and with fewer clicks.


Enhanced Visibility in Work Center Capacity Management

The Manage Work Center Capacity app now provides even greater transparency into your operations. Planners and supervisors can now view the associated Customer name and ID directly in a new column, which is especially useful for linking capacity requirements to specific make-to-order scenarios.

Customer name and Customer ID

Additionally, the application now clearly displays the Consolidated Shift Capacity and the Remaining Capacity.

Remaining capacity and consolidated shift capacity

 

This gives teams a more comprehensive view of utilization, helping them make more informed scheduling and load-leveling decisions to optimize the shop floor. 

 

Summary 

These highlights from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.1 update are designed to bring tangible value to your manufacturing and production planning processes. By improving user experience and providing deeper analytical insights, we are continuing our commitment to helping you run your operations more intelligently and efficiently. I encourage you to explore these new capabilities and see how they can benefit your team.

 

ATTENTION: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025 - COMING UP 

A must for all SAP Partners worldwide! 

For the first time, we’re covering the full range of SAP Business Suite, incl. topics such as SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), Spend Management, Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Experience (CX), Human Capital Management (HCM), and more, setting a new benchmark in SAP training.

Check it out and see you there!
